sentence.text: This girl was the first child of healthy apparently non-consanguineous Brazilian parents.
Prenatal ultrasound revealed club foot and congenital heart defect.
She was born at term with a weight of 2.8 kg and length of 44 cm.
She had a flat midface, grooved nasal tip, and crumpled ears (Fig. 2A).
Cardiac ultrasound showed that the congenital heart defect consisted of atrial and ventricular septal defects.
Congenital bilateral cataracts were detected at day 2 of age.
The left leg was shorter than the right as a consequence of hip dysplasia/luxation and tibial hemi-melia (left tibia was truncated at the midshaft level) (Fig. 2B).
Abdominal ultrasound, audiological evaluation, and karyotype were all normal.
Tracheostomy was performed at one month of age because of laryngomalacia and gastrostomy because of gastroesophageal reflux.
An umbilical hernia was corrected at 2.5 years of age and the gastrostomy tube was removed at that time.
Her motor development was delayed but intelligence was within normal limits.
At age 2 years and 3 months, her growth parameters were weight 8.8 kg (<5th centile), height (<5th centile), and head circumference 46.5 cm.
Radiographs taken at 2 months of age, showed coronal clefts in all lumbar vertebrae and epiphyseal delay (Fig. 1).
The repeat radiographs at 2 years and 3 months showed resolution of the coronal clefts leaving only an indentation.
There was persistent epiphyseal delay with no visible ossification of the capital femoral epiphyses and microepiphyses at both knees.
A chevron deformity was present at both distal femurs.
There was also a delay in carpal bone ossification.
